title: Prefixes — Un-, Re-, Pre-, Dis-
description: Students learn how prefixes change word meanings. They study four common prefixes: un- (not), re- (again), pre- (before), dis- (opposite of). They build new words by adding prefixes to base words and explore how prefix knowledge unlocks vocabulary.
instructions:
1. Introduce the concept: a prefix is a word part added to the BEGINNING.
2. Present un- (not): happy → unhappy, kind → unkind.
3. Present re- (again): read → reread, build → rebuild.
4. Present pre- (before): heat → preheat, view → preview.
5. Present dis- (opposite): agree → disagree, like → dislike.
6. Practice building words with prefix cards.
7. Write sentences using prefixed words.

items: Prefix cards: un-, re-, pre-, dis-
Chart paper for prefix reference chart
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare prefix cards in one color and base word cards in another. Create a four-column chart labeled with each prefix. Have base words that work with multiple prefixes (e.g., 'do' works with un-do and re-do).

slides.text: A PREFIX is a word part added to the BEGINNING of a word that changes its meaning. Think of it like a code: if you know what the prefix means, you can figure out new words even if you have never seen them before! Today we learn four powerful prefixes that unlock HUNDREDS of English words.

UN- means NOT or the opposite. Happy becomes UNhappy (not happy). Kind becomes UNkind (not kind). Lock becomes UNlock (the opposite of locking). RE- means AGAIN or back. Read becomes REread (read again). Build becomes REbuild (build again). Turn becomes REturn (turn back). These two prefixes alone appear in thousands of words!

PRE- means BEFORE. Heat becomes PREheat (heat before cooking). View becomes PREview (view before the main show). History becomes PREhistory (before written history — we studied this!). DIS- means OPPOSITE OF or NOT. Agree becomes DISagree. Like becomes DISlike. Appear becomes DISappear (the opposite of appearing). Connect becomes DISconnect.

slides.prompt: Match prefix cards with base word cards to build as many real words as you can. Record each word in your journal with its meaning. Challenge: Can you find base words that work with MORE than one prefix? (Example: 'cover' → uncover, recover, discover). Then write 8 sentences, using at least 2 words with each prefix (un-, re-, pre-, dis-). Underline each prefixed word and circle the prefix.

slides.text: You now have four prefix keys that unlock hundreds of English words. When you encounter an unfamiliar word in reading, check: does it start with un-, re-, pre-, or dis-? If so, remove the prefix, find the base word, then add the prefix meaning back. UNfamiliar? That is un- (not) + familiar = not familiar! You just used your new skill!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child define un-, re-, pre-, and dis-, build at least 5 words with each prefix, and determine meaning of unfamiliar prefixed words?

parent_notes: Prefix knowledge is one of the most powerful vocabulary strategies because it is generative — knowing four prefixes helps decode hundreds of words. Make this practical: when your child encounters an unknown word in reading, model the strategy of breaking it apart. The Montessori approach to word study emphasizes the logical structure of language, and prefixes are a perfect example. Consider making a prefix wall chart that the child adds to throughout the year. Latin and Greek roots (introduced in week 18) combined with prefix knowledge creates a powerful word-analysis toolkit.

title: Multiplication Mastery — Mixed Facts Review
description: Students review all multiplication tables learned so far (2s through 9s and 10s) with a focus on building fluency and speed. They identify their personal trouble facts, create targeted practice strategies, and take a comprehensive multiplication assessment.
instructions:
1. Warm-up: skip count by 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10.
2. Complete a full multiplication chart from memory.
3. Identify trouble spots — which facts are hardest?
4. Practice trouble facts with targeted strategies.
5. Take a timed mixed-facts assessment (50 problems).
6. Record results and set improvement goals.
7. Celebrate mastery!

items: Flash cards for all multiplication tables (2-10)
Assessment sheet with 50 mixed multiplication problems
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a blank multiplication chart and a 50-problem mixed assessment. Include problems from ALL tables, weighted toward the harder facts (6x7, 7x8, 8x9, etc.). Have flash cards sorted and ready. This is a celebration of learning — keep the tone positive and encouraging.

slides.text: You have learned ALL the multiplication tables from 2 through 10! That is an incredible achievement. Today we put it all together. First, let us fill in the ENTIRE multiplication chart from memory. Start with the facts you know best (2s, 5s, 10s) to build confidence, then fill in the rest.

Everyone has a few TROUBLE FACTS — the ones that just will not stick. The most commonly difficult facts are: 6x7=42, 6x8=48, 7x8=56, 8x9=72, and 6x9=54. Which ones trip YOU up? Write them on a special card. We will practice these extra hard.

Memory tricks for trouble facts: 6x7=42 (six times seven is FORTY-TWO, like the answer to everything!). 7x8=56 (5-6-7-8, the numbers go in order!). 8x8=64 (I ate and I ate until I was sick on the floor — 8x8=64). 6x8=48 (six times eight is FORTY-EIGHT). 8x9=72 (eight times nine, the digits of 72 add to 9!).

slides.prompt: Step 1: Fill in the entire multiplication chart from memory (time yourself). Step 2: Circle any facts you had to think hard about — these are your trouble facts. Step 3: Practice your trouble facts 10 times each with flash cards. Step 4: Take the 50-problem mixed assessment. Record your score and time. Step 5: In your math journal, write your 5 hardest facts and a memory trick for each.

slides.text: Knowing your multiplication tables is like having a superpower in math. Division, fractions, algebra — everything gets easier when multiplication is automatic. You have worked incredibly hard to learn these facts, and that effort will pay off for years to come. Keep practicing your trouble facts daily — even just 2 minutes makes a difference!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child complete a multiplication chart with at least 90% accuracy, identify personal trouble facts, and solve mixed multiplication problems with increasing fluency?

parent_notes: This review lesson celebrates the monumental achievement of learning multiplication tables. Fluency develops at different rates — some children will be lightning-fast while others still need to think through certain facts. Both are normal. The goal is not instant recall of every fact (that comes with continued practice) but rather having reliable strategies for every fact. The 50-problem assessment should be approached positively — it measures progress, not perfection. Aim for 90%+ accuracy. Speed will come with continued daily practice. Consider keeping a multiplication chart visible in your learning space for ongoing reference.

title: The Age of Exploration — Magellan's Circumnavigation
description: Students learn about Ferdinand Magellan's extraordinary attempt to sail around the entire world (1519-1522). They trace his route through the strait that bears his name, across the Pacific Ocean, and learn that while Magellan died in the Philippines, his crew completed the first circumnavigation of the globe.
instructions:
1. Review Columbus (west to Americas) and da Gama (east to India).
2. Introduce Magellan: could you sail ALL THE WAY around the world?
3. Trace the route: Spain → South America → Strait of Magellan → Pacific.
4. Describe crossing the Pacific: 99 days without seeing land.
5. Tell the story of Magellan's death in the Philippines.
6. Elcano completes the voyage: 3 years, 1 ship of 5 returned.
7. The child traces the full route and records in journal.

items: World map or globe (globe is especially useful)
String for measuring the route's length on a globe
slides.setup_instructions: A globe is ideal for this lesson because it shows the true scale of Magellan's voyage, especially the vast Pacific crossing. Mark 1519-1522 on the timeline. Prepare to trace the route in stages. Have string ready to measure the total distance on the globe.

slides.text: Columbus proved you could sail west across the Atlantic. Da Gama proved you could sail east around Africa. But could someone sail ALL THE WAY AROUND the world? In 1519, Ferdinand MAGELLAN set out from Spain with 5 ships and 270 men to find a western route to the Spice Islands by sailing AROUND South America and across the Pacific Ocean.

Magellan sailed south along South America searching for a passage through the continent. After months of searching, he found a narrow, twisting waterway at the very southern tip — now called the STRAIT OF MAGELLAN. It took 38 days to navigate the treacherous strait, with whirlpools, rocks, and fierce winds. One ship deserted and sailed home. But Magellan pressed on into an unknown ocean.

He named it the PACIFIC Ocean because it seemed so calm and peaceful compared to the storm-tossed strait. But the Pacific was ENORMOUS — far bigger than anyone imagined. For 99 DAYS they sailed without seeing land. The crew ran out of food. They ate rats, sawdust, and boiled leather from the rigging. Many died of scurvy. It was the most desperate voyage in history.

Magellan reached the Philippines in March 1521, but he was killed in a battle with local warriors on the island of Mactan. His crew, led by Juan Sebastian ELCANO, continued westward. Of the original 5 ships and 270 men, only 1 ship (the Victoria) and 18 men made it back to Spain in September 1522 — THREE YEARS after they left. They had sailed completely around the world for the first time in human history!

slides.prompt: Trace Magellan's complete route on a world map: Spain → Atlantic → South America coast → Strait of Magellan → Pacific Ocean → Philippines (mark X where Magellan died) → Spice Islands → Indian Ocean → around Africa → back to Spain. Use string on a globe to measure the total distance. In your journal, create a voyage timeline with key dates and events. Write: Why is this considered one of the greatest voyages ever? What does it prove about the shape of the Earth?

slides.text: Magellan's voyage proved once and for all that the Earth is a SPHERE and that all the oceans are connected. It showed just how vast the Pacific Ocean is — much bigger than anyone had guessed. The cost was terrible: 252 of 270 men died, including Magellan himself. But the 18 survivors accomplished something no human had ever done: they sailed completely around our planet.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child trace Magellan's route on a map, explain why the voyage was significant, describe the major challenges, and explain how the circumnavigation proved the Earth is round?

parent_notes: Magellan's circumnavigation is one of history's greatest adventure stories and children find it gripping. Use a globe rather than a flat map if possible — it dramatically shows the Pacific's vastness. The human cost of the voyage (252 of 270 men died) provides an honest look at the true price of exploration. Discuss: Was it worth it? This is an excellent opportunity for moral reasoning. The distinction between Magellan (who planned the voyage but died midway) and Elcano (who completed it) raises interesting questions about credit and legacy. Magellan gets the fame, but Elcano actually sailed around the world.

title: Weather Patterns — How Weather Systems Move
description: Students learn how weather systems form and move across the globe. They explore how temperature differences create wind, how air masses interact to create fronts, and how weather generally moves from west to east in the mid-latitudes due to prevailing winds.
instructions:
1. Review ocean currents and their effect on weather.
2. Introduce air masses: large bodies of air with uniform temperature.
3. Explain warm fronts and cold fronts: what happens when air masses meet.
4. Demonstrate with warm and cold water in a tank.
5. Discuss prevailing westerlies: weather moves west to east.
6. Read a simple weather map with front symbols.
7. Record in geography journal.

slides.heading: Weather Patterns
slides.subheading: How Weather Systems Move Across the Globe

items: Simple weather map showing fronts and pressure systems
World map showing prevailing wind patterns
Clear container, warm water (red food coloring), cold water (blue food coloring)
slides.setup_instructions: Print a simple weather map showing cold fronts (blue triangles) and warm fronts (red semicircles). Prepare the temperature demonstration: a clear container of room-temperature water, plus warm colored water and ice water to add. Show how they interact.

slides.text: Last week we learned about ocean currents — rivers in the sea. The ATMOSPHERE has similar patterns! Large bodies of air called AIR MASSES form over different surfaces: warm air masses form over tropical oceans, cold air masses form over Arctic regions. These air masses are constantly moving, and when they MEET, interesting weather happens!

When a COLD AIR MASS pushes into a warm air mass, it creates a COLD FRONT (shown on maps as a blue line with triangles). Cold air is heavier, so it wedges UNDER the warm air, pushing it up rapidly. This creates tall thunderstorm clouds, heavy rain, and sometimes severe weather. After the cold front passes, the air becomes cooler and clearer.

When a WARM AIR MASS slides over a cold air mass, it creates a WARM FRONT (shown as a red line with semicircles). Warm air rises gently OVER the cold air, creating wide layers of clouds. Warm fronts bring long periods of gentle rain or drizzle. After a warm front passes, temperatures rise and skies gradually clear.

In North America and Europe, weather generally moves from WEST to EAST. This is because of the PREVAILING WESTERLIES — winds that blow from west to east in the mid-latitudes (30-60 degrees). So if it is raining in Ohio today, it will probably rain in Pennsylvania tomorrow! Weather forecasters use this pattern to predict what is coming your way.

slides.prompt: Study the weather map. Identify cold fronts (blue triangles) and warm fronts (red semicircles). Predict: what weather will each city experience as the fronts pass? In your journal, draw a diagram showing how a cold front works (cold air wedging under warm air, creating tall clouds) and a warm front (warm air sliding over cold air, creating layered clouds). Then check today's actual weather forecast: are any fronts approaching your area?

slides.text: Weather is not random — it follows patterns created by moving air masses and the fronts where they meet. Cold fronts bring dramatic storms; warm fronts bring gentle rain. Weather moves west to east in our latitudes. Now when you watch a weather forecast, you understand the SCIENCE behind those moving symbols on the map!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain what air masses are, describe the difference between cold and warm fronts, and predict weather changes based on approaching fronts?

parent_notes: Weather is immediately relevant to daily life, making it an engaging topic. The temperature demonstration (warm and cold colored water meeting in a clear container) beautifully shows how air masses interact. Check the weather forecast together and identify approaching fronts. Many weather apps show frontal boundaries on their maps. The west-to-east pattern is a powerful predictor — if relatives or friends live to your west, their weather today may be your weather tomorrow! Consider starting a simple weather journal where your child records daily temperature, conditions, and any frontal passages. This builds observational skills and connects to the scientific method.

title: Read Aloud — Sarah, Plain and Tall, Chapters 1-3
description: Begin reading Patricia MacLachlan's Sarah, Plain and Tall. Students meet Anna, Caleb, and Papa on their prairie homestead, and learn that Papa has placed an advertisement for a wife. Sarah Elisabeth Wheaton from Maine answers the ad, and the family awaits her arrival with hope and anxiety.
instructions:
1. Introduce the book: Sarah, Plain and Tall by Patricia MacLachlan.
2. Discuss the setting: a prairie farm in the late 1800s.
3. Read chapters 1-3 aloud.
4. Discuss: Why did Papa advertise for a wife? How do Anna and Caleb feel?
5. Notice MacLachlan's spare, poetic writing style.
6. Discuss the theme of longing and belonging.
7. The child writes about what home means to them.
materials_needed: Sarah, Plain and Tall by Patricia MacLachlan
Map showing Maine and the prairie states

items: Sarah, Plain and Tall by Patricia MacLachlan
Map showing Maine (northeast coast) and the prairie (Kansas/Nebraska area)
slides.setup_instructions: This short novel (58 pages) is a Newbery Medal winner with spare, beautiful prose. Read slowly and let the silences in the text breathe. Show the map to establish the enormous distance between Maine and the prairie. The book deals with loss of a mother — be sensitive if this is relevant to your family.

slides.text: Sarah, Plain and Tall is about a family and what it means to call a place HOME. Anna and Caleb live with their Papa on a prairie homestead. Their mother died after Caleb was born. The house is quiet without her singing. Papa decides to place an advertisement in the newspaper for a wife — something people actually did in the 1800s on the frontier.

A woman named SARAH ELISABETH WHEATON writes back from Maine, far away on the coast. She describes herself as 'plain and tall.' She will come for a trial visit. Anna and Caleb are full of questions: What will she be like? Will she sing? Will she STAY? The children's longing for a mother figure is the heart of the story.

Notice how Patricia MacLachlan writes: short sentences, simple words, but deeply emotional. 'Did Mama sing every day?' asked Caleb. 'Every-single-day.' Every word counts. The prairie landscape — vast, flat, treeless — mirrors the emptiness in the family. MacLachlan uses very few words to say very big things. Listen for the rhythm of her prose.

slides.prompt: On a map, find Maine and the prairie states. How far would Sarah have to travel? What would she leave behind (ocean, green hills, family) and what would she find (flat land, wheat fields, a new family)? In your reading journal, write about what HOME means to you. What would you miss most if you moved far away? What would make a new place feel like home? Draw the prairie homestead as you imagine it from chapters 1-3.

slides.text: Sarah, Plain and Tall asks one of life's biggest questions: What makes a place HOME? Is it the landscape, the people, or both? Anna and Caleb are hoping Sarah will fill the silence their mother left behind. Sarah is considering leaving everything she knows for a new life. Both sides are taking a brave leap. As we read on, we will see if courage and love can build a new kind of family.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe the family's situation, explain why Papa advertised for a wife, identify MacLachlan's spare writing style, and reflect on the concept of home?

parent_notes: Sarah, Plain and Tall is a masterpiece of children's literature — every word is carefully chosen. The spare prose makes it accessible to younger readers while the themes of loss, belonging, and blended families resonate deeply with older children and adults. Read slowly and discuss the emotional undercurrents. The historical context (mail-order brides, frontier life, 1800s) connects to your history studies. The prairie setting contrasts with Maine's coast, creating a rich geography connection. If your child has experienced family changes (divorce, remarriage, loss), this book may bring up feelings — let those conversations happen naturally. MacLachlan's writing is a model of economy and beauty that influences all writing going forward.

title: Suffixes — -ful, -less, -ness, -ly
description: Students learn how suffixes change word meanings and parts of speech. They study four common suffixes: -ful (full of), -less (without), -ness (state of being), and -ly (in a certain way). They explore how combining prefix and suffix knowledge creates powerful vocabulary tools.
instructions:
1. Review prefixes from Day 1. Introduce suffixes: added to the END.
2. Present -ful (full of): care → careful, hope → hopeful.
3. Present -less (without): care → careless, hope → hopeless.
4. Present -ness (state of being): kind → kindness, dark → darkness.
5. Present -ly (in a way): quick → quickly, gentle → gently.
6. Build words with suffix cards.
7. Combine prefixes AND suffixes on a single base word.

items: Base word cards (many shared with prefix lesson)
Prefix cards from Day 1 (un-, re-, pre-, dis-)
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare suffix cards in a third color (distinct from prefix and base word colors). Include base words that work with both prefixes and suffixes (e.g., 'care' → careful, careless, uncaring). This lesson builds directly on the prefix lesson.

slides.text: On Day 1, we learned PREFIXES go at the beginning. Today: SUFFIXES go at the END! Together, prefixes and suffixes are called AFFIXES — they are word parts that attach to base words to create new words. A suffix often changes the PART OF SPEECH: 'care' is a noun/verb, but 'careful' is an adjective, and 'carefully' is an adverb!

-FUL means FULL OF: care + ful = careful (full of care). Hope + ful = hopeful. Joy + ful = joyful. -LESS means WITHOUT: care + less = careless (without care). Hope + less = hopeless. Fear + less = fearless. Notice something amazing: -ful and -less are OPPOSITES! Careful vs. careless. Hopeful vs. hopeless. Fearful vs. fearless!

-NESS turns adjectives into NOUNS (naming words): kind → kindNESS (the state of being kind). Dark → darkNESS. Happy → happiNESS (notice: y changes to i!). -LY turns adjectives into ADVERBS (how words): quick → quickLY (in a quick way). Gentle → gentLY. Beautiful → beautifulLY. These are incredibly useful for writing!

slides.prompt: Build as many words as you can using suffix cards. Then try the ULTIMATE CHALLENGE: add BOTH a prefix AND a suffix to one base word! Examples: un-care-ful (not careful = not caring), un-kind-ness (the state of being unkind), dis-respect-ful (full of disrespect). How many triple-layer words can you build? Write 8 sentences using suffix words. Star any sentences that use BOTH a prefix word and a suffix word.

slides.text: With prefixes and suffixes together, you can decode thousands of English words! When you see a long, unfamiliar word, break it into parts: prefix + base word + suffix. 'Unhappiness' is un- (not) + happy (base) + -ness (state of being) = the state of being not happy. You are becoming a word detective!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child define -ful, -less, -ness, and -ly, build words with each suffix, explain how suffixes change parts of speech, and combine prefixes and suffixes on base words?

parent_notes: Suffix study pairs naturally with the prefix lesson to give children a complete toolkit for word analysis. The -ful/-less opposition is particularly powerful — children enjoy discovering that adding different suffixes creates opposite meanings. The spelling change with -ness (happy → happiness, y→i) previews spelling rules they will encounter more formally later. Encourage your child to look for these suffixes in their reading. MacLachlan's Sarah, Plain and Tall uses many suffix words (carefully, kindness, loneliness) that your child can now analyze. Building words with both prefixes AND suffixes (unhappiness, disrespectfully) develops morphological awareness — understanding word structure — which is one of the strongest predictors of reading comprehension.

title: Division — Connecting to Multiplication
description: Students deepen their understanding of division as the inverse of multiplication. Using their multiplication mastery, they solve division problems by thinking 'what times what equals this number?' They practice fact families and solve division word problems.
instructions:
1. Review: division is sharing equally or grouping.
2. Connect to multiplication: 6 x 7 = 42, so 42 / 7 = 6 and 42 / 6 = 7.
3. Practice fact families: 3, 8, 24 → 3x8=24, 8x3=24, 24/3=8, 24/8=3.
4. Use multiplication chart BACKWARDS to solve division.
5. Solve division word problems.
6. Practice with Montessori division board.
7. Record strategies in math journal.

slides.heading: Division and Multiplication
slides.subheading: Two Sides of the Same Coin

items: Montessori division board with skittles and beads
slides.setup_instructions: Display the multiplication chart and show how to read it 'backwards' for division. Set up the Montessori division board. Prepare word problems that use real-world sharing contexts. Emphasize that knowing multiplication GIVES you division for free.

slides.text: Here is the most powerful math secret: if you know your multiplication facts, you ALREADY know your division facts! Division is multiplication in REVERSE. When you see 56 divided by 8, just think: 'What times 8 equals 56?' You know 7 x 8 = 56, so 56 / 8 = 7! Your multiplication mastery just doubled in usefulness!

Every multiplication fact lives in a FACT FAMILY of four related equations. Take the numbers 6, 7, and 42: 6 x 7 = 42 (multiplication), 7 x 6 = 42 (commutative), 42 / 7 = 6 (division), 42 / 6 = 7 (division). Four equations, three numbers, one relationship. If you know ANY one of these, you know all four!

On the division board, let us verify: place 42 beads among 7 skittles (sharing equally). Each skittle gets 6 beads. 42 / 7 = 6. Now rearrange: 42 beads among 6 skittles. Each gets 7. 42 / 6 = 7. The board PROVES what multiplication tells us. As you get faster, you will not need the board — you will just think of the multiplication fact.

slides.prompt: Write the complete fact family for each set of numbers: (4, 9, 36), (7, 8, 56), (6, 9, 54), (8, 8, 64 — this one only has 2 unique equations! Why?). Then solve 20 division problems using your multiplication knowledge: 48/6, 72/9, 35/5, 63/7, 81/9, 54/6, 32/8, 45/9, 56/7, 42/6, 27/3, 36/4, 64/8, 30/5, 49/7, 72/8, 24/6, 40/8, 63/9, 28/4. Finally, solve: A baker made 72 cookies and packed them in boxes of 8. How many boxes?

slides.text: You did not have to memorize 100 new facts for division — you already knew them from multiplication! This is the beauty of mathematical relationships: learning one thing teaches you another. From now on, whenever you see a division problem, your first thought should be: 'What multiplication fact does this connect to?' That is thinking like a mathematician.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child write complete fact families, solve division problems by recalling multiplication facts, and apply division to word problems?

parent_notes: The multiplication-division connection is one of the most empowering realizations in elementary math. Children who struggled with division as a separate concept often find it clicks instantly when connected to multiplication they already know. The Montessori division board provides concrete verification. The fact family concept (4 related equations from 3 numbers) builds algebraic thinking. The special case of square numbers (8x8=64 has only 2 unique equations instead of 4) is a nice mathematical observation. Continue daily multiplication practice — division fluency depends entirely on multiplication fluency. Word problems should emphasize both 'sharing' (48 cookies among 6 friends) and 'grouping' (48 cookies in groups of 6) interpretations of division.

title: Light — Refraction and Bending Light
description: Students explore how light bends when passing from one material to another, a phenomenon called refraction. They experiment with pencils in water, observe how lenses work, and learn that refraction is what makes eyeglasses, magnifying glasses, and cameras possible.
instructions:
1. Review reflection (light bouncing). Introduce refraction (light bending).
2. Demonstrate: pencil in a glass of water appears bent.
3. Explain why: light slows down in water, causing it to bend.
4. Experiment with different materials: water, oil, glass.
5. Introduce lenses: curved glass that bends light in useful ways.
6. Explore magnifying glasses as convex lenses.
7. Record observations in science journal.

items: Pencil or straw for bending demonstration
Small clear container with cooking oil
slides.setup_instructions: Fill a clear glass with water. Have the pencil ready to place in the water at an angle. The magnifying glass is a key prop — children will examine how it bends light. If you have a prism, keep it ready for the rainbow demonstration.

slides.text: Last week we learned that light REFLECTS (bounces off mirrors). Today: light can also BEND! This is called REFRACTION. Put a pencil in a glass of water and look from the side — the pencil appears to be BROKEN or bent at the water's surface! But pull it out — perfectly straight! The pencil did not bend. The LIGHT bent as it passed from air into water.

WHY does light bend? Light travels at different speeds in different materials. In air, light travels very fast. In water, it slows down a little. In glass, it slows down more. When light changes speed, it changes DIRECTION — just like a car pulling onto sand from pavement will veer to one side because one wheel slows down first. This speed change causes the bending.

LENSES use refraction on purpose! A MAGNIFYING GLASS is a convex lens — it is thicker in the middle than at the edges. Light passing through it bends INWARD, concentrating the light at a focal point. This is why a magnifying glass makes things look bigger — it bends the light so your eye sees an enlarged image. Your EYES have lenses too, bending light to focus images on your retina!

slides.prompt: Experiment 1: Place a pencil in water at different angles. Draw what you see from the front and from the side. Experiment 2: Try the same with cooking oil — does the pencil bend more or less? (Oil bends light more than water!) Experiment 3: Hold a magnifying glass over text. Move it slowly closer and farther — at what distance is the text biggest? What happens when you move it very far away? (It flips upside down!) In your journal, explain refraction in your own words and draw a diagram of light bending as it enters water.

slides.text: Refraction makes modern life possible! Without it, we would have no eyeglasses, no cameras, no microscopes, no telescopes, and our own eyes would not work. Every time you look through a window, wear glasses, use a camera, or peer through a magnifying glass, you are using refraction. Light bending is one of nature's most useful tricks!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain what refraction is, demonstrate it with a pencil in water, explain why light bends (speed change), and describe how lenses use refraction?

parent_notes: Refraction is visually striking and easy to demonstrate at home. The pencil-in-water experiment is so compelling that children often want to try many different objects. The oil comparison is revealing — light bends more in oil than water, which is why diamonds sparkle so brilliantly (they bend light dramatically). The magnifying glass exploration naturally leads to discussion of eyeglasses: nearsighted people need lenses that spread light out; farsighted people need lenses that focus light in. If your child wears glasses, this lesson explains WHY they work. The upside-down image at distance is surprising and fun — it is how cameras and our eyes actually work (our brains flip the image right-side up!). Connect to explorers: telescopes and navigational instruments all depend on refraction.

title: Watercolor Landscapes — Prairie Scenes
description: Inspired by Sarah, Plain and Tall, students paint watercolor landscapes depicting the vast prairie. They learn to create a sense of depth with a low horizon line, practice wet-on-wet technique for big skies, and explore how landscape art captures the feeling of a place.
instructions:
1. Discuss the prairie setting in Sarah, Plain and Tall.
2. Show images of prairie landscapes and paintings.
3. Teach the low horizon line: sky dominates prairie paintings.
4. Demonstrate wet-on-wet technique for sky washes.
5. Paint the sky first, then the prairie grass.
6. Add details: farmhouse, windmill, wildflowers.
7. Discuss how the painting captures the FEELING of the prairie.

slides.heading: Prairie Watercolors
slides.subheading: Painting the Vast Landscape of Sarah's New Home

items: Watercolor paper (heavier weight holds water better)
Large brush for sky washes, small brush for details
Cup of water and paper towels
Images of prairie landscapes (photos and paintings)
slides.setup_instructions: Display prairie images — emphasize the enormous sky and flat land. Lightly pencil the horizon line about one-third from the bottom of the paper. Demonstrate the wet-on-wet technique: wet the paper above the horizon, then drop in sky colors. Have paper towels ready for blotting.

slides.text: In Sarah, Plain and Tall, the prairie is a CHARACTER in the story. MacLachlan describes the flat land stretching to the horizon, the enormous sky, and the waving grass. Sarah misses the ocean, but the prairie has its own beauty — endless space, dramatic sunsets, wildflowers in summer. Today we paint that landscape.

Prairie paintings have a special composition: the HORIZON LINE is very LOW, often just one-third from the bottom. This makes the SKY enormous — which is exactly right, because on the prairie, the sky IS enormous. The land is flat and stretches forever. There are few trees. The feeling is one of vastness, openness, and sometimes loneliness.

We will use WET-ON-WET technique for the sky. First, wet the paper above your horizon line with clean water. Then drop in colors: blue at the top, lighter blue in the middle, maybe pink or orange near the horizon for a sunset glow. The colors will blend and spread on the wet paper — this creates the soft, luminous sky that makes watercolor so beautiful. Let it dry before painting the land.

slides.prompt: Paint your prairie landscape: 1) Lightly pencil a low horizon line. 2) Wet the sky area and drop in watercolors — let them blend naturally. 3) While the sky dries, plan your land details. 4) Paint the prairie grass in greens and golds. 5) Add a small farmhouse or barn (small = far away = depth!). 6) Add details: wildflowers, a windmill, a fence, birds. Think about the FEELING you want: peaceful? Lonely? Beautiful? Wide open? Let the painting express that feeling.

slides.text: A landscape painting captures not just what a place LOOKS like, but what it FEELS like. The enormous sky in your prairie painting communicates the vastness and openness that Sarah experienced. Art and literature work together: MacLachlan paints the prairie with words; you paint it with watercolors. Both capture the truth of a place.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child use a low horizon line to create a prairie composition, apply wet-on-wet technique for sky washes, and express the mood of a landscape through artistic choices?

parent_notes: This lesson beautifully integrates art with literature — painting the setting of the book they are reading. The wet-on-wet technique produces gorgeous, unpredictable results that children love. The key to success: use ENOUGH water (the paper should be shiny-wet before dropping in color), and do not overwork it (let the colors blend on their own). If the first attempt does not satisfy, watercolor paper is inexpensive — try again! The low horizon line composition principle applies to all landscape art and photography. Compare your child's painting to the prairie descriptions in the book: does the painting capture the same feeling? This cross-curricular connection deepens understanding of both the art and the literature.

title: Practical Life — Pioneer Butter Making
description: Connecting to the prairie homestead setting of Sarah, Plain and Tall, students make butter from heavy cream using the traditional method of shaking cream in a jar. They learn about the science of butter (fat separation) and the daily tasks of pioneer life.
instructions:
1. Connect to Sarah, Plain and Tall: what did pioneer families do daily?
2. Explain butter making: cream contains fat globules suspended in liquid.
3. Shaking breaks the fat globules, which clump together into butter.
4. Pour heavy cream into a jar, seal tightly.
5. Shake vigorously for 15-20 minutes (take turns!).
6. Strain off buttermilk, rinse butter, add salt.
7. Taste on fresh bread. Record the process.

items: 1 cup heavy whipping cream (room temperature works faster)
Clean glass jar with tight-fitting lid (mason jar is perfect)
Fresh bread or crackers for tasting
slides.setup_instructions: Take the cream out of the refrigerator 30 minutes before the lesson — room temperature cream churns faster. Ensure the jar lid is TIGHT (you will be shaking vigorously!). This activity requires sustained physical effort — plan for turn-taking and arm rests.

slides.text: In Sarah, Plain and Tall, the family lives on a prairie homestead where they grow and make much of their own food. One essential daily task was making BUTTER. Before supermarkets, every family with a cow made their own butter by churning cream. Today we make butter the same way pioneers did — with muscle power!

The SCIENCE of butter: cream is a mixture of water, protein, and tiny globules of FAT floating in the liquid. When you shake cream vigorously, those fat globules bump into each other and stick together, forming larger and larger clumps. Eventually, the fat separates completely from the liquid (called BUTTERMILK). The solid clumps are BUTTER!

Pour the cream into the jar (fill it only halfway so there is room to slosh). Seal the lid TIGHTLY. Now SHAKE! Shake hard and steadily. After about 5 minutes, the cream will thicken into whipped cream. Keep going! After 10-15 more minutes, you will suddenly feel a CLUNK — that is the butter separating from the buttermilk. You will see a solid lump and thin liquid. You did it!

slides.prompt: Make butter! Time each stage: How long until whipped cream forms? How long until butter separates? Strain off the buttermilk (save it — you can drink it or use it in pancakes). Rinse the butter under cold water, pressing out remaining buttermilk. Add a pinch of salt and knead it in. Spread on bread and taste YOUR butter! In your journal, draw the process step by step and explain the science: why does shaking turn liquid cream into solid butter?

slides.text: You just did something pioneer families did every week! Making butter connects us to a time when people made their food from scratch. The science is real: mechanical agitation causes fat globules to coalesce. And the taste? Homemade butter is richer and fresher than store-bought because it is JUST cream and salt. Sarah would have made butter just like this on the prairie!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain the science of butter making (fat separation), successfully make butter from cream, and describe how this connects to pioneer daily life?

parent_notes: Butter making is a beloved Montessori practical life activity that connects science, history, and cooking. The cream must be shaken vigorously for 15-20 minutes — take turns! Room temperature cream churns faster than cold. The transformation from liquid to whipped cream to solid butter is dramatic and exciting. The 'clunk' moment when butter separates is genuinely thrilling. Save the buttermilk for pancakes or biscuits. Homemade butter is delicious but will not last as long as store-bought (no preservatives) — use it within a few days, refrigerated. This activity connects directly to the pioneer homestead setting of Sarah, Plain and Tall, making the historical period tangible. The science connection (emulsions, fat coalescence) is real chemistry happening in a jar.

title: Root Words — Building a Word-Analysis Toolkit
description: Students combine their prefix and suffix knowledge with root word study. They learn common Latin and Greek roots (port, rupt, struct, scrib) and practice building complex words by assembling root + prefix + suffix combinations.
instructions:
1. Review prefixes and suffixes from Days 1 and 2.
2. Introduce the concept of ROOT WORDS — the core meaning carrier.
3. Present root 'port' (to carry): transport, import, export, portable.
4. Present root 'rupt' (to break): erupt, interrupt, disrupt, rupture.
5. Present root 'struct' (to build): construct, instruct, structure, destruct.
6. Present root 'scrib/script' (to write): describe, inscribe, manuscript, prescription.
7. Build complex words: prefix + root + suffix (e.g., de-struct-ion).
8. Students create root word trees in their journals.
9. Practice decoding unfamiliar words using all three word parts.
10. Write sentences using root-based words.

items: Root word cards: port, rupt, struct, scrib/script
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare root word cards in yet another color to distinguish from prefix and suffix cards. Create sample word trees on chart paper showing how one root generates many words. Have a dictionary available for verification.

slides.text: You know prefixes (beginning) and suffixes (ending). Now meet the most important piece: the ROOT. A root is the core of a word — it carries the main meaning. Most English roots come from Latin or Greek. If you know the root, you can figure out words you have never seen before!

ROOT: PORT means 'to carry.' TRANSport = carry ACROSS. IMport = carry IN. EXport = carry OUT. PORTable = ABLE to be carried. REport = carry BACK (bring back information). SUPport = carry from BELOW (hold up). One root, six words — and there are dozens more!

ROOT: RUPT means 'to break.' eRUPT = break OUT (a volcano erupts). interRUPT = break BETWEEN (break into someone's speech). disRUPT = break APART. bankRUPT = completely broken (financially). ROOT: STRUCT means 'to build.' conSTRUCT = build together. deSTRUCT = un-build, tear down. inSTRUCT = build knowledge IN someone.

Now the ULTIMATE skill: combine ALL THREE parts. De-STRUCT-ion = the act of (ion) un-building (de+struct). In-SCRIPT-ion = something written (script) into (in) a surface, with the noun ending (ion). Trans-PORT-ation = the act of (ation) carrying (port) across (trans). You can decode almost ANY English word!

slides.prompt: Create ROOT WORD TREES in your journal. Draw a tree trunk for each root (port, rupt, struct, scrib). On each branch, write a word that uses that root. Label the prefix and suffix on each word. Try to get at least 5 words per root. Then decode these challenge words using your prefix + root + suffix knowledge: 'destruction,' 'transportation,' 'prescription,' 'interruptible.' Write each word's meaning based on its parts.

slides.text: You now have a complete word-analysis toolkit: prefixes, suffixes, AND roots. When you encounter an unfamiliar word, break it into parts: What is the root? Any prefix? Any suffix? Put the meanings together and you can figure out words that would stump most people. This is how vocabulary scholars work — and now you can too!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify roots in complex words, combine prefix + root + suffix to determine meaning, and build word families from common roots?

parent_notes: Root word study is the capstone of morphological analysis. Combined with prefixes and suffixes, it gives children a systematic strategy for decoding unfamiliar vocabulary. The four roots introduced today (port, rupt, struct, scrib) generate dozens of common English words. The word tree activity is visually powerful and helps children see word families as connected. Encourage your child to become a 'word detective' in daily reading. When they encounter an unfamiliar word, guide them through the analysis: Can you find a root? A prefix? A suffix? This strategy works for thousands of English words derived from Latin and Greek.

title: Long Division — Single-Digit Divisors with the Racks and Tubes
description: Students are introduced to long division using the Montessori racks and tubes material. They learn the systematic process of dividing a multi-digit number by a single-digit divisor, connecting the concrete manipulation to the written algorithm.
instructions:
1. Review division as sharing equally from Day 2.
2. Introduce the racks and tubes material for long division.
3. Present the problem: 846 divided by 3.
4. Set up the dividend (846) with tubes and the divisor (3) with skittles.
5. Begin with hundreds: share 8 hundreds among 3 groups (2 each, 2 remaining).
6. Exchange remaining 2 hundreds for 20 tens, add to existing 4 tens = 24 tens.
7. Share 24 tens among 3 groups (8 each, 0 remaining).
8. Share 6 units among 3 groups (2 each).
9. Read the quotient: 282. Record the written algorithm alongside.
10. Practice with 2-3 more problems.

items: Montessori racks and tubes (or division board)
slides.setup_instructions: Set up the racks and tubes material on a large work mat. Prepare problems with single-digit divisors that divide evenly at first (846/3, 936/4, 555/5), then introduce remainders later. Write each problem on a card. Have the written algorithm modeled alongside the manipulative work.

slides.text: Division with small numbers is easy when you know your multiplication facts. But what about dividing BIG numbers like 846 by 3? That is what LONG DIVISION is for — a step-by-step method that breaks a big division into smaller, manageable steps. The racks and tubes help us SEE what is happening.

Set up 846 on the tubes: 8 hundred tubes, 4 ten tubes, 6 unit tubes. Place 3 skittles as the divisor — we are sharing among 3 groups. Start with the BIGGEST place value: hundreds. Share 8 hundreds among 3 groups. Each group gets 2 hundreds (that uses 6). We have 2 hundreds LEFT OVER.

What do we do with 2 leftover hundreds? EXCHANGE them for tens! 2 hundreds = 20 tens. Add those 20 tens to the 4 tens already there: 24 tens total. Now share 24 tens among 3 groups. Each group gets 8 tens (3 x 8 = 24). Zero tens remaining. Perfect!

Finally, share 6 units among 3 groups. Each gets 2 units (3 x 2 = 6). Zero remaining. Read the quotient: each group has 2 hundreds, 8 tens, 2 units = 282! So 846 divided by 3 = 282. Check: 282 x 3 = 846. It works! Now let us write this as the standard long division algorithm.

slides.prompt:
Use the racks and tubes (or draw the process) to solve these long division problems. For each, also write the standard long division algorithm:
1. 936 divided by 4
2. 555 divided by 5
3. 738 divided by 6
4. 672 divided by 3
Check each answer by multiplying the quotient by the divisor. Record all work in your math journal.

slides.text: Long division looks complicated on paper, but it is really just sharing — one place value at a time, from biggest to smallest, exchanging leftovers as you go. The racks and tubes make this visible. With practice, you will be able to do the written algorithm on its own, but always remember: long division is just organized sharing!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child set up a long division problem with the racks and tubes, work through each place value systematically, exchange remainders correctly, and connect the process to the written algorithm?

parent_notes: Long division is often considered the most challenging arithmetic algorithm, but the Montessori racks and tubes make it concrete and logical. The key insight: start with the largest place value and work down, exchanging remainders as you go. This is exactly what the written algorithm does, but the manipulative makes it visible. Do not rush to the abstract algorithm — let the child work with the material until the process is internalized. The check step (multiply quotient by divisor) builds good mathematical habits. If your child struggles, return to simpler division problems on the division board before attempting multi-digit division.

title: The Age of Exploration — Impact on Indigenous Peoples
description: Students learn about the profound and often devastating impact of European exploration on indigenous peoples around the world. They discuss the Columbian Exchange, the introduction of diseases, and the importance of understanding multiple perspectives in history.
instructions:
1. Review the explorers studied: Columbus, da Gama, Magellan.
2. Ask: What happened to the people who ALREADY lived in the places explorers visited?
3. Introduce the Columbian Exchange: goods, plants, animals, and diseases that moved between the Old and New Worlds.
4. Positive exchanges: potatoes, tomatoes, corn went to Europe; horses, wheat went to the Americas.
5. Devastating impact: diseases (smallpox, measles) killed millions of indigenous people who had no immunity.
6. Discuss forced labor, displacement, and loss of culture.
7. Why is it important to learn BOTH sides of the story?
8. The child writes about the Columbian Exchange from two perspectives.

items: World map showing Old World and New World
Columbian Exchange chart (items that went each direction)
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a two-column chart showing what went from the Americas to Europe/Africa/Asia and vice versa. Include plants, animals, technologies, and diseases. This is a sensitive topic — present facts honestly but age-appropriately. Focus on empathy and multiple perspectives.

slides.text: We have studied exploration from the European perspective — brave sailors crossing unknown seas. But there is another side to every story. When Europeans arrived in the Americas, Africa, and Asia, they encountered people who had been living there for THOUSANDS of years. What happened to THOSE people? Understanding their experience is essential to understanding history honestly.

The COLUMBIAN EXCHANGE was the transfer of plants, animals, and ideas between the Old World (Europe, Asia, Africa) and the New World (the Americas). Some exchanges were beneficial: potatoes, tomatoes, corn, and chocolate went from the Americas to Europe, transforming diets worldwide. Horses, cattle, wheat, and sugar went from Europe to the Americas.

But the most devastating exchange was invisible: DISEASES. Europeans unknowingly carried smallpox, measles, and influenza. Indigenous peoples had never encountered these diseases and had no immunity. Entire communities were wiped out. Historians estimate that 90% of the indigenous population of the Americas died from European diseases in the century after contact. This was the greatest loss of life in human history.

Beyond disease, many indigenous peoples faced forced labor, displacement from their lands, and destruction of their cultures. It is important to understand that the Age of Exploration was a time of both discovery AND destruction. Good historians look at events from MULTIPLE PERSPECTIVES — not just the winners' side of the story.

slides.prompt: Create a Columbian Exchange chart: two columns showing what went each direction between the Old and New Worlds. Include at least 8 items. Use green for beneficial exchanges and red for harmful ones. Then write TWO short paragraphs about the arrival of Columbus: one from Columbus's perspective and one from the perspective of the Taino people who already lived on the island. How does the same event look different depending on who is telling the story?

slides.text: Understanding multiple perspectives is one of the most important skills a historian can have. The Age of Exploration brought the world together, but at a terrible cost to indigenous peoples. When we study history honestly — including the painful parts — we learn empathy and wisdom. We cannot change the past, but we can learn from it.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe the Columbian Exchange with specific examples, explain the devastating impact of disease on indigenous peoples, and write about a historical event from two different perspectives?

parent_notes: This is an important but sensitive lesson. Children at this age can understand fairness and empathy, making this an appropriate time to introduce the concept of multiple perspectives in history. The Columbian Exchange provides a balanced framework: some exchanges were mutually beneficial, while others were devastating. The disease impact is historically accurate and helps children understand that the most destructive forces are not always intentional. The dual-perspective writing exercise builds critical thinking. Avoid presenting history as simple good-vs-evil; help the child understand complexity. This lesson lays the groundwork for understanding colonialism, civil rights, and social justice in later studies.

title: Climate Zones of the World — Tropical, Temperate, and Polar
description: Students learn about Earth's three major climate zones and how latitude determines climate. They explore the relationship between distance from the equator and temperature, and map the zones on a world map.
instructions:
1. Review latitude lines and the equator.
2. Introduce the three climate zones: tropical (near equator), temperate (middle latitudes), polar (near poles).
3. Explain WHY: the equator gets direct sunlight, the poles get angled sunlight.
4. Demonstrate with a flashlight and globe: direct vs. angled light.
5. Tropical zone: hot year-round, between the Tropics of Cancer and Capricorn.
6. Temperate zone: four seasons, moderate temperatures.
7. Polar zone: cold year-round, above Arctic/below Antarctic circle.
8. Color-code the zones on a world map.
9. Identify which zone they live in.
10. Record in geography journal.

slides.setup_instructions: Darken the room for the flashlight-globe demonstration. Prepare a blank world map with latitude lines marked. The demonstration showing direct vs. angled sunlight is the key visual that makes climate zones click.

slides.text: Have you noticed that some places on Earth are always hot (like the Amazon rainforest) and some are always cold (like Antarctica)? This is not random — it depends on how far a place is from the EQUATOR. The Earth has three major CLIMATE ZONES, like temperature belts that wrap around the planet.

WHY does latitude matter? Shine a flashlight straight down on the globe at the equator — the light hits a small, bright circle. Direct sunlight = more heat. Now tilt the flashlight to hit the poles — the same light spreads over a much larger area. Angled sunlight = less heat per area. This is why the equator is hot and the poles are cold!

The TROPICAL ZONE wraps around the equator between the Tropic of Cancer (23.5 degrees N) and the Tropic of Capricorn (23.5 degrees S). It is hot year-round with abundant rainfall. The TEMPERATE ZONES lie between the tropics and the polar circles — they have four distinct seasons and moderate temperatures. The POLAR ZONES are above the Arctic Circle and below the Antarctic Circle — cold year-round with long dark winters.

Most of the world's population lives in the TEMPERATE zones because the climate is comfortable and good for farming. But incredible life thrives in ALL zones: tropical rainforests have the most biodiversity, and polar regions have uniquely adapted animals like polar bears and penguins. Where do YOU live? Which climate zone?

slides.prompt: On your blank world map: 1) Draw and label the equator, Tropics of Cancer and Capricorn, and Arctic and Antarctic circles. 2) Color the tropical zone RED, temperate zones GREEN, and polar zones BLUE. 3) Label each zone. 4) Mark your location — which zone are you in? 5) In your journal, write 3 characteristics of each zone and name 2 countries in each zone.

slides.text: Climate zones explain so much about our world: why certain plants grow where they do, why animals have different adaptations, why human cultures developed differently in different latitudes. The sun's angle — determined by latitude — is the master key to understanding Earth's climates. Next time you hear a weather report from another part of the world, think: what climate zone is that in?
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and locate the three climate zones, explain WHY the equator is warmer than the poles, and identify which zone they live in?

parent_notes: The flashlight-globe demonstration is one of the most effective science-geography activities. It makes the abstract concept of climate zones concrete and visual. The key insight — direct sunlight heats more than angled sunlight — explains not just climate zones but also seasons. Children often ask why it is hot in summer and cold in winter; this demonstration answers both questions (seasons result from Earth's tilt changing the angle of sunlight). Connecting climate zones to the biomes studied earlier deepens understanding. Knowing which climate zone they live in helps children understand their local weather patterns in a global context.

title: Read Aloud — Sarah, Plain and Tall, Chapters 4-6
description: Students continue reading Sarah, Plain and Tall. Sarah has arrived at the prairie homestead and the family is getting to know her. Students observe how Sarah brings the sea to the prairie through her stories, songs, and the colors she paints.
instructions:
1. Review chapters 1-3: Sarah is coming from Maine.
2. Read chapters 4-6 aloud.
3. Discuss: Sarah has arrived — what does she bring with her?
4. Notice the sea imagery: shells, sand, the color blue.
5. How does Sarah adapt to prairie life? What does she miss?
6. How are Anna and Caleb changing now that Sarah is here?
7. Discuss the theme: Can you love a new place while still missing the old one?
8. The child writes about a time they missed a place or person.
materials_needed: Sarah, Plain and Tall by Patricia MacLachlan

items: Sarah, Plain and Tall by Patricia MacLachlan
slides.setup_instructions: Bookmark chapters 4-6. Prepare to read with emotion — these chapters are tender and full of sensory detail. Sarah's descriptions of Maine and the sea contrast beautifully with the prairie setting.

slides.text: When we left off, Sarah was on her way from Maine. Now she has ARRIVED. As we read, notice what Sarah brings with her — not just physical things, but memories, songs, and the colors of the sea. Notice how MacLachlan uses very few words to show very deep feelings.

Read chapters 4-6 aloud. Let the silences breathe. Notice how Sarah brings the SEA to the prairie: she brings shells, she describes the ocean, she paints with blue. The sea is part of who Sarah IS. Can she bring that part of herself to this new, very different place?

After reading, discuss: How is the family changing? Anna is starting to hope — but she is also afraid Sarah will leave. Caleb asks directly: 'Will you stay?' Children are often braver with big questions than adults. Sarah is learning to love the prairie, but she misses the sea. Can you love two places at once?

Notice MacLachlan's craft: Sarah says she will sing for them. Remember — the house has been silent since their mother died. Singing is not just music; it is LIFE returning to the home. Every detail in this book carries emotional weight. 'She does not have to sing,' said Caleb. 'But I want her to.'

slides.prompt: In your reading journal: 1) List everything Sarah brings from Maine (physical objects AND memories/stories). 2) Draw the prairie homestead with Sarah in it — show her bringing sea colors to the prairie. 3) Write about a time YOU missed a place, a person, or something familiar. How did you cope? Did you eventually find happiness in the new situation? Connect your experience to Sarah's.

slides.text: Sarah, Plain and Tall is about the courage it takes to build a new life while honoring the old one. Sarah does not forget Maine — she brings it with her. The sea shells on the prairie windowsill are a symbol: you do not have to leave your past behind to embrace your future. That is a lesson for all of us.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe how Sarah is adapting to prairie life, identify the sea imagery and its significance, and connect Sarah's experience of missing a place to their own life?

parent_notes: These middle chapters are the emotional heart of the book. MacLachlan's genius is showing Sarah's internal struggle through small, concrete details: the shells, the blue paint, the singing. Children who have experienced any kind of transition (moving, changing schools, family changes) will connect deeply. The question 'Can you love two places at once?' is powerful — most children have experienced this in some form. The writing prompt about missing a place or person invites genuine reflection. Read slowly and let the child respond emotionally before analyzing. Sometimes the best response to a chapter is a quiet moment of feeling.

title: Word Origins and Etymology — Where Do Words Come From?
description: Students explore the fascinating origins of English words. They learn that English borrows from many languages and discover the stories behind common words. They use dictionaries to look up etymologies and create an illustrated word-origin poster.
instructions:
1. Review roots, prefixes, and suffixes from earlier this week.
2. Introduce etymology: the study of where words come from.
3. English is a borrower! Words from Latin, Greek, French, German, Arabic, and more.
4. Fun word origins: 'sandwich' (Earl of Sandwich), 'volcano' (Vulcan, Roman god).
5. Words from other languages: 'kindergarten' (German), 'piano' (Italian), 'algebra' (Arabic).
6. Show how to find etymology in a dictionary.
7. Students research the origins of 10 interesting words.
8. Create an illustrated word-origin poster.
9. Share discoveries with the class or family.
10. Discuss: Why does English borrow so many words?

items: Etymology dictionary or child-friendly online etymology resource
Large poster paper for word-origin poster
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a list of 20 words with interesting etymologies for the child to research. Include words from daily life. If using an online resource, bookmark an age-appropriate etymology site. A physical etymology dictionary is ideal for browsing.

slides.text: This week we learned that many English words are built from Latin and Greek parts. But English is the greatest BORROWER of all languages! Over its history, English has taken words from French, German, Spanish, Arabic, Hindi, Japanese, and dozens of other languages. Every borrowed word has a STORY — and that story is called its ETYMOLOGY.

Some word origins are amazing stories! The word SANDWICH was invented because the Earl of Sandwich wanted to eat without leaving his card game — he asked for meat between bread so he could hold it with one hand. VOLCANO comes from Vulcan, the Roman god of fire. ROBOT comes from a Czech word meaning 'forced labor.' Every word has a history!

Words borrowed from other languages: KINDERGARTEN is German for 'children's garden.' PIANO is Italian for 'soft' (the instrument could play soft AND loud). ALGEBRA is Arabic for 'reunion of broken parts.' CHOCOLATE comes from the Aztec word 'xocolatl.' TSUNAMI is Japanese for 'harbor wave.' The world is in our words!

When you look up a word in the dictionary, after the definition you will often find its etymology in brackets. It might say [from Latin portare, to carry] or [from Old French]. Learning to read etymologies is like being a word archaeologist — digging up the buried history of language!

slides.prompt: Research the origins of 10 words and create a colorful WORD ORIGIN POSTER. For each word: write the word in large letters, its language of origin, its original meaning, a small illustration, and one sentence using the word. Choose from: volcano, chocolate, piano, robot, algebra, kindergarten, tsunami, safari, karate, pajamas, banana, zero, shampoo. Or research any words that interest you!

slides.text: English is one of the richest languages in the world BECAUSE it borrows from everywhere. Every time English speakers encountered a new culture, they adopted new words. Your vocabulary is a map of human history — Latin words from the Roman Empire, French words from the Norman Conquest, Arabic words from the Islamic Golden Age, and words from every culture English speakers have encountered. Language is alive, always growing, always borrowing!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain what etymology means, identify the language of origin for several common words, use a dictionary to find etymologies, and create an informative word-origin display?

parent_notes: Etymology is endlessly fascinating and turns vocabulary study into a treasure hunt. Children love discovering that everyday words have exotic origins. This lesson builds on the root word study from Day 3 and extends it to word history. An etymology dictionary is a wonderful investment — children can browse it like an adventure book. The poster activity produces a display piece that reinforces learning every time the child sees it. Encourage ongoing etymology exploration: when your child encounters a new word, make it a habit to ask 'I wonder where that word comes from?' This builds curiosity and a deeper relationship with language. English's borrowing nature also teaches cultural interconnection — our language reflects our history of contact with the world.

title: Long Division — Solving Problems with Remainders
description: Building on the introduction to long division, students learn what happens when division does not come out evenly. They discover remainders, learn to express them correctly, and understand their meaning in real-world contexts.
instructions:
1. Review long division from Day 3.
2. Present a problem that does not divide evenly: 85 divided by 4.
3. Work through with racks and tubes: 8 tens shared among 4 = 2 each, 0 remaining.
4. 5 units shared among 4 = 1 each, 1 remaining.
5. The 1 left over is the REMAINDER: 85 / 4 = 21 R 1.
6. Discuss: What does the remainder MEAN in real life?
7. Context matters: 85 cookies among 4 friends = 21 each with 1 left over.
8. But 85 students in 4 buses = you need 22 buses (round up!).
9. Practice 5 problems with remainders.
10. Check answers: quotient x divisor + remainder = dividend.

slides.heading: Division with Remainders
slides.subheading: What Happens When It Does Not Divide Evenly?

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare problems that result in remainders. Start with simple ones (13/4 = 3 R 1) before moving to larger numbers. Include word problems where the remainder has different real-world meanings. The check strategy (quotient x divisor + remainder = dividend) is essential.

slides.text: Yesterday we divided numbers that came out EVENLY — no leftovers. But in real life, division does not always work out perfectly. What if you have 13 cookies to share among 4 friends? Each person gets 3 cookies (4 x 3 = 12), but there is 1 cookie left over. That leftover is called the REMAINDER.

Let us solve 85 divided by 4 with our racks and tubes. 8 tens shared among 4: each gets 2 tens, 0 remaining. Now 5 units shared among 4: each gets 1 unit, but 1 unit is LEFT OVER — it cannot be shared equally. We write: 85 / 4 = 21 remainder 1, or 21 R 1.

Here is the important part: the remainder must ALWAYS be LESS than the divisor. If you are dividing by 4, the remainder can be 0, 1, 2, or 3 — never 4 or more! Why? Because if you had 4 left over, you could share one more round. This is a great way to CHECK your work.

In real life, what you DO with the remainder depends on the CONTEXT. 85 cookies among 4 friends: 21 each, 1 left over (cut it or save it). 85 students in buses that hold 4: you need 22 buses (round UP — you cannot leave a student behind!). 85 inches of ribbon cut into 4-inch pieces: you get 21 pieces with 1 inch of scrap. Same math, different decisions!

slides.prompt:
Solve these division problems and express the remainder:
1. 47 / 3
2. 95 / 6
3. 129 / 8
4. 250 / 7
For each, CHECK: quotient x divisor + remainder = dividend.
Then solve these word problems and decide what to do with the remainder:
5. 23 students need to ride in cars that hold 4. How many cars?
6. You have 50 stickers to share equally among 7 friends. How many does each get? How many are left?

slides.text: Remainders are a natural part of division — not every number divides evenly. The key skills are: calculate the remainder correctly, check that it is less than the divisor, verify with multiplication plus the remainder, and decide what the remainder MEANS in context. Division with remainders is real-world math!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child perform long division with remainders, verify answers using the check strategy, and interpret remainders appropriately in word problem contexts?

parent_notes: Remainders are where division meets real-world thinking. The most powerful part of this lesson is the contextual interpretation: the same mathematical remainder (1 left over) leads to different decisions depending on the situation (leave the extra cookie, but you cannot leave an extra student!). This develops critical thinking about when to round up, round down, or report the remainder as-is. The check strategy (quotient x divisor + remainder = dividend) should become automatic — it prevents errors and builds good mathematical habits. Encourage your child to encounter division in daily life: sharing snacks, dividing time, splitting costs.

title: Light — Color and the Visible Spectrum
description: Students discover that white light is actually a mixture of all colors. They use prisms to split white light into the rainbow spectrum and learn about wavelengths. They explore how objects get their color by absorbing some wavelengths and reflecting others.
instructions:
1. Review refraction from Day 2.
2. Ask: Where do colors come from? Is color in the light or in the object?
3. Use a prism to split white light into the spectrum: red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo, violet.
4. Explain: White light contains ALL colors mixed together.
5. Each color has a different wavelength: red is longest, violet is shortest.
6. Why is a red apple red? It ABSORBS all colors except red, which it REFLECTS to your eyes.
7. Why is grass green? It absorbs all colors except green.
8. Mix colored lights: red + green + blue = white (additive mixing).
9. The child creates a color wheel spinner that appears white when spun.
10. Record observations in science journal.

items: Glass prism (or CD/DVD as a substitute)
White paper or wall for projecting the spectrum
Cardboard, colored pencils, and string for color spinner
slides.setup_instructions: A glass prism works best, but a CD or DVD can also split light into a rainbow. Direct sunlight through a prism produces the most vivid spectrum. For the spinner, cut a circle from cardboard, divide into 7 sections, color each with a spectrum color, poke two holes in the center, and thread a loop of string through.

slides.text: Yesterday we learned that light bends when it passes through different materials. Today we discover something incredible: white light is not just one color — it is ALL the colors mixed together! When white light passes through a prism, the different colors bend by different amounts, and they SEPARATE into a beautiful rainbow: red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo, violet. ROY G. BIV!

Each color is a different WAVELENGTH of light. Red has the longest wavelength — like big, slow ocean waves. Violet has the shortest wavelength — like quick little ripples. When all the wavelengths are mixed together, we see WHITE. When they separate, we see the rainbow. Newton discovered this with a prism in 1666!

Now the big question: WHY is a red apple red? The apple is not making red light — it is REFLECTING it. White light (all colors) hits the apple. The apple's surface ABSORBS orange, yellow, green, blue, and violet light — soaks them up like a sponge. But it REFLECTS red light back to your eyes. You see red! Every colored object is absorbing some wavelengths and reflecting others.

Here is a fun consequence: a black object absorbs ALL colors (that is why black gets hot in sunlight — it absorbs all the light energy). A white object reflects ALL colors (that is why white stays cooler). And if you spin a wheel with all the rainbow colors fast enough, your eyes see... WHITE! The colors blend together. Let us try it!

slides.prompt: Experiment 1: Shine light through a prism onto white paper. Can you see all 7 colors? Draw and label the spectrum in your journal. Experiment 2: Make a color spinner — divide a cardboard circle into 7 sections, color each with a rainbow color, thread string through two center holes, and spin it. Does it look white or grayish-white? Experiment 3: Predict — what color does a green leaf reflect? What colors does it absorb? Write your explanation.

slides.text: Color is one of nature's most beautiful phenomena, and now you understand the science behind it. White light contains all colors. Objects get their color by reflecting certain wavelengths and absorbing others. A rainbow is simply white light separated into its component wavelengths. Newton, prisms, and your own eyes reveal this hidden truth: the white light around you is secretly a rainbow!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain that white light contains all colors, name the spectrum colors in order, explain how objects get their color through selective reflection, and demonstrate color mixing with a spinner?

parent_notes: Color science is magical for children — and the experiments are easy to set up. A glass prism is inexpensive and produces stunning results in direct sunlight. The color spinner is a classic physics demonstration; it may not appear perfectly white due to imperfect color mixing, but it should appear noticeably lighter than any single section. The absorption/reflection explanation of color is profound: children realize that color is not IN objects but is a product of how objects interact with light. Black absorbing all light explains why dark cars get hotter — a practical connection. The ROY G. BIV mnemonic helps with spectrum order. Connect to art: mixing paints works differently from mixing light (subtractive vs. additive color mixing).

title: Music Appreciation — Folk Songs of the American Frontier
description: Students explore folk songs from the American frontier era, connecting to Sarah, Plain and Tall and the pioneer theme. They learn that folk songs told stories, preserved history, and built community. They learn to sing a traditional folk song and discuss its meaning.
instructions:
1. Connect to Sarah, Plain and Tall: Sarah sings for the family.
2. Introduce folk music: songs passed down by ordinary people.
3. Explain: folk songs told stories, taught lessons, and entertained.
4. Listen to or sing 'Home on the Range' — a classic prairie song.
5. Analyze the lyrics: What does the song tell us about frontier life?
6. Listen to 'Oh Susanna' — a song about traveling west.
7. Listen to 'Simple Gifts' — a Shaker song about contentment.
8. Discuss: How do these songs make you FEEL? What do they reveal about the people who sang them?
9. The child learns the words and melody of one song.
10. Discuss: What songs do WE sing today that tell stories?
materials_needed: Recordings of folk songs (or ability to sing them)

items: Recordings of: Home on the Range, Oh Susanna, Simple Gifts
Printed lyrics sheets for each song
slides.setup_instructions: Queue up recordings of the three folk songs. Print lyrics for each. If you play an instrument, learn the melodies beforehand. The connection to Sarah, Plain and Tall is powerful — Sarah's singing brings life back to the quiet house. These songs evoke the same era and landscape.

slides.text: In Sarah, Plain and Tall, one of the most important moments is when Sarah SINGS. The house had been silent since the children's mother died. Music has the power to bring life, joy, and community. The songs of the American frontier — called FOLK SONGS — were exactly this kind of life-giving music.

FOLK SONGS are songs created by ordinary people and passed down through generations, often by singing rather than writing. They told stories of daily life, expressed emotions, and built community. On the prairie, where families lived far apart, singing was one of the most important forms of entertainment and connection.

Listen to 'Home on the Range': 'Oh, give me a home where the buffalo roam, where the deer and the antelope play, where seldom is heard a discouraging word, and the skies are not cloudy all day.' This song paints a picture of the ideal prairie life — space, animals, peace, and beauty. It became the state song of Kansas!

Now listen to 'Simple Gifts': 'Tis the gift to be simple, 'tis the gift to be free, 'tis the gift to come down where we ought to be.' This Shaker song is about finding happiness in simplicity — not needing more, but appreciating what you have. This philosophy connects perfectly to prairie life and to Sarah's choice to leave Maine for a simpler life.

slides.prompt: Choose one folk song to learn by heart. Write the lyrics in your journal and illustrate the scene the song describes. Then answer: What story does this song tell? What emotions does it express? What does it reveal about the people who sang it? Finally, write your own short 'folk song' (4-8 lines) about YOUR daily life. What would you want people 100 years from now to know about how you live?

slides.text: Folk songs are time capsules — they preserve the voices, feelings, and stories of people who lived long ago. When you sing 'Home on the Range,' you are singing the same words that pioneer families sang around their campfires. Music connects us across time. Sarah's singing brought life back to a quiet house, and folk songs continue to bring us the voices of the past.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain what folk songs are, identify themes in frontier folk songs, connect folk music to the pioneer lifestyle, and create a simple original folk song?

parent_notes: Folk songs are a natural integration of music, history, and literature. The connection to Sarah, Plain and Tall makes the music emotionally resonant — singing was essential to frontier life. If you play an instrument, accompany the songs; if not, recorded versions work fine. Singing together is the most important part. Children do not need to sing perfectly — the goal is experiencing the music and understanding its cultural context. The creative writing exercise (writing their own folk song) is surprisingly powerful: children take it seriously and produce charming, honest verses about their lives. Consider learning several folk songs as a family tradition.

title: Practical Life — Basic Hand Sewing: Running Stitch and Buttons
description: Connecting to pioneer self-sufficiency, students learn basic hand sewing skills. They master threading a needle, tying a knot, the running stitch, and sewing on a button. These are practical skills that foster independence, fine motor control, and patience.
instructions:
1. Connect to pioneer life: families made and repaired their own clothing.
2. Materials introduction: needle, thread, fabric, scissors, buttons.
3. Safety first: needles are sharp tools, not toys. Handle with care.
4. Demonstrate threading a needle: lick the thread end, push through the eye.
5. Demonstrate tying a knot at the end of the thread.
6. Teach the running stitch: up-down-up-down through the fabric.
7. Practice running stitch on a practice cloth.
8. Teach sewing on a button: position, stitch through holes, secure.
9. The child sews a button onto a piece of fabric.
10. Discuss: Why is sewing a valuable skill for everyone?

items: Large-eye sewing needles (embroidery needles work well)
Felt fabric scraps (easier to sew than woven fabric)
slides.setup_instructions: Cut felt into manageable rectangles (about 6x8 inches). Pre-thread a few needles for demonstration.
